description:
This hole in the wall feels so authentically Yucatacan and the food is orgasmic. There's a lot of Mexican in the Bay Area but not like this since they serve food from the yucatacan region which is different from just tacos and burritos. This place is for the adventurous foodie who likes to try cultural cuisines. 

The best 
-their handmade tortillas 
-salbute and panucho are kind of like tacos but even better 
-empanadas with cheese (the tomato sauce is to die for)

We didn't get a chance to try the por chuc but next time!
author: Dianna Y.

description:
Although I've had bad experiences before I was never inclined to write a review until now. I've had pleasant experiences with holes in the wall when it comes to authenticity but the customer service has truly turned me away. There were no more than 7 customers including my friend and I, the owner showed us our table and fixed it as it seemed to have a broken leg once we sat. One of the two waitress took our order and thus began the waiting game. More than 25 minutes passed and my friend got his food, I tried to grab the waitress attention and asked her to cancel my appetizer but the owner jumped in and told the cooks to cancel my order. So not only did I have to wait more than 25 minutes now I was not going to get to eat? The owner and cooks were arguing and ignoring my requests but thankfully I was able to tell the waitress that I had not asked to cancel my order and they brought out the food a while later with no apologies and seemed annoyed as the arguing continued in the kitchen.

Tl;Dr:

Food: 3/10  
Service: 1/10
Health Score of 88 hidden behind the register.

It's true that you get what you pay for so take your business somewhere else.
author: Paloma P.

description:
Being from Mexico, I honestly can say this is authentic. Fresh tortillas, tender tamales , juicy panuchos , and great Cochinita, just like the kind you will get in the best spots in my country. 

And Jarritos ! That beverage reminds me of my childhood !
author: Roberto V.

description:
Delicious food from the yucatan peninsula, best Yucatan cuisine in the city of San Francisco. 
The Poc-Chuc is my favorite
author: Abraham L.

description:
Wow.  Was not expecting such delicious and flavorful food at midnight after a concert.  We ordered pork on a tortilla puff and grilled pork with black bean purée.  The meat was well seasoned and grilled to perfection.

The tortilla puff was incredibly flavorful and the pork went really well the purée.  Surprisingly good!
author: Thomas B.

description:
I would never have guessed that El Rincon Yucateco was a legit Mexican spot until we popped in randomly for some late night bites after grabbing some drinks in Tenderloin.

I usually get my Mexican fix at Mission or San Jose in South Bay. We came upon this spot by accident after walking down from a nearby bar. As a pescatarian, I was unsure about my food options...but luckily they had a fried fish dish that came with rice and beans. I'm not one to get fried fish, but I decided to go for it and start with a veggie empanada which was filled with cheese. Bae got the carne tamale and the infamous poc-chuc which is marinated pork. We both thought the food was above average for a more indigenous style of Mexican food...it wasn't the commonplace Americanized-Mexican cuisine, which we enjoyed. My empanada was not the flaky kind that I prefer, but a fried one that was much smaller in size and less filling. It was alright, I wouldn't necessarily order it again. The fried fish was surprisingly yummy and flavorful...and although the salad part was kind of a weird component in my opinion, I did like the sides of rice and soupy beans. My fooding partner said the poc-chuc was good, but he had better marinated pork on a blacktop fajitas plate elsewhere.

Service is minimal and small, as the shop itself is small and seemingly family-owned. The food server is also the cashier, and he is a hardworking and friendly dude. Hats off to you, sir! They had a lot of to-go food orders with people walking out with take-out boxes, and smaller groups of 2 to 4 walking in to enjoy an in-house dinner. I wouldn't come here in a large group, as space is limited...also the ambiance is lacking. Nothing looks entirely pleasing to the eye and there is no music being played, so feel free to people-watch to your heart's delight!
author: Jodi H.

description: Very tasty and real home-made quality. Hand-made tortillas are thick and delicious. The Cuchinita Pibil was fabulous and the sauce didn't need any help for flavor. That said, part way through, I did squeeze in some lime AND I sprinkled the yellow chili sauce ("aji amarillo"?) --which adds a bright, clean hot flash and a lovely fresh chili taste. So good!
author: J.Fred D.

description:
Came here last night with my friends, but wasn't too big of a fan of this place. To be fair, I don't really eat Mexican cuisine much and I felt that this is more of a 3.5 stars review than a 3. So you should take my review with a skeptical eye.

I ordered the Milanesa (Chicken), which contained breaded chicken, a side salad with avocado, rice, and bean purée. It's a big bang for your buck because there's a lot of food for $12.50. The chicken was crispy and it was deeply fried. So I would recommend this dish if you stop by. However to me, the rice had an odd aftertaste to it and the bean purée was not that good. The purée was super liquidly and I mainly dipped my tortilla in it. 

My friend got the Zalado and it was sort of disappointing. It came with like three thinly slices of pork, some cabbage, and the bean purée. The portion was really small for what it cost and he probably was still hungry after the meal. It's funny because his dish costed more than my dish. 

My other friend got the Puchero and I wasn't a big fan of that dish either. The meat to noodle portion was way off. There was just way too much chicken with the bones attached on it. 

If I could give a tip, I would suggest that they have pictures on the menu. I thought I knew how my friend's dishes were going to be presented, but I was way off. This is random, but I thought having a sink in the dining area was actually amusing. Really set the vibe of a hole in the wall.
author: Victor L.

description: So I paid $13 for rice, beans and two tacos stacked on top of each other. The beans had 1 bean in it. The rest was watery bean soup. In a leaking plastic case. They charged me $3 for bean soup. The pork taco was all chunks of pork fat. Hardly any meat. The tacos had no flavor. It felt like I bought 2 ingredients like lettuce and the cheapest meat I could find and kinda threw them together. It was flavorless, watery, and the tortillas were soaked through so I couldn't even pick them up. One of the worst dining experiences I've had. Don't recommend.
author: Lisa O.

description:
It was all right. Cheap food means cheap meats though. But what was I expecting? Good flavors in the sauces. I spent a lot of time chewing tough, gristly, not so flavorful meat. I had the Panucho and a tamale. Habanero sauce is super hot but adds a great flavor. 

A neighbor had the Rellenos Blanco which was a creamy soup with chicken and chicken livers. If I go back, I'd try that. But that's a pretty big IF. Too many great Mexican places to go again for me.
author: Genie O.

description:
Wow. Great hole-in-the-wall Mexican food, open late and with friendly service. I had the zalado, which is a combo plate of strips of tender, slightly salty marinated pork, tasting a bit like a delicate ham. It came with a cup of bean paste, shredded cabbage, sliced avocado, and a generous number of handmade tortillas, as well as a squirt bottle of very flavorful habanero salsa. The tortillas were really nice, and the flavors of everything blended well. I will definitely keep this in mind for late-night near Union Square, and really any time I'm in the area.

UPDATE: I came back twice while staying nearby for a conference. One friend commented that he'd eat lunch here everyday if he could. The soups were good and the various meat dishes were excellent, especially with the homemade tortillas, awesome habanero salsa, and lime. Highly recommend this place.
author: Cage H.

description:
Excellent hole in the wall greasy yucatean food! Panuchos and Tamales were amazing ! Ate the chicken tamale so fast I didn't get a chance to take a picture. 

Make sure to ask for the habanero salsa if you want to add that additional spice!
author: Sasha S.

description:
A hole in the wall diamond in the ruff. They make some of the best Mexican food in the city. Small menu with a homemade flavor. Excellent service! Fantastic food!

Tamales and empanadas on point.
author: Dorsey S.

description:
This place is alright.

I've been here twice now and both times it was decent. 

Pros:
- its cheap
- the food Is decent
- orders don't take long to make
- its open late
- they serve menudo on sunday

Cons:
- the food is just alright
- the hot sauce its pretty wack

I would​ come back...
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
This place has absolutely terrible service. I couldn't get seated even though the place was not even half full, so I sat myself and had to flag the waitress down for the menus. 

I also had to wait even longer even after I flagged her down to order, where she straight up ignored me and kept talking to the guy behind the counter. When we ordered, we also ordered two cups of water, which came after, you guessed it, another unreasonable delay. 

The person I was trying to eat with asked to leave after the food took even longer to come out, but I maintained hope for 5 minutes longer. At this point we had enough of that and we just decided to eat elsewhere. I would not recommend this place to anybody who wants to eat within two hours on a lazy Sunday evening.
author: Cj J.

description: This place is delicious and so close to the real thing it fooled my Mexican wife!  The tortillas are excellent and hand made.  Worth the flight from Maryland!  Thank you Yucatecos!  Btw we had caldo de res and Puc Chuc, both were excellent!
author: Brent M.

description: This place is so good!! The best Mexican food is in the TL not the mission. I get there appetizers, there plate dishes are the bees knees as well, highly recommend.
author: Maxwell D.

description: Yucatan food holds a special place in my stomach's heart ever since I roamed the street of Tulum. Lucky for me San Francisco has abundant supply of Yucatan specialized restaurants. I was very excited to try El Rincon Yucateco as it was very well-reviewed. The restaurant ambience is casual. There was a group of 20 something year olds merrily discussing their favorite food. I orderd a sampler of panucho, salbute and tamal colado. The panucho with pork was delicious, not as tasty, or as big, as the one i got in Mexico ironically (everything in the US is supposed to be bigger.) After this, the rest of the food was disappointing. The salbute with chicken was definitively bland. The tamal colado with ground pork was a little off in terms of the spices that they used. It was not very tasty albeit the properly tender white masa. Even though it was wrapped in banana leaves I could not smell any fragrance that you would expect from banana leaves. Overall, I'm glad I visited it, but I'm not sure if I will come back because there is way better Yucatan food elsewhere.
author: Thuy V.

description:
This place makes me feel right at home--perfunctory soccer game playing on the tv, music blaring in the kitchen, fans running on overdrive.  It's a greasy spoon, sparse joint, but the panuchos are really good.  They weren't overly greasy or messy, and the pork was delicious.  The tacos were delicious too, and I'd opt for the chicken over the pork.  They were filled to the brim, and the handmade tortilla everything sat on was perfect.  I hold a hearty appetite, and the one salbute, two panuchos, and one taco were enough to fill me up for dinner at $14.  My dog jealously looked on as I chowed down on my take out order at home.  

Next time I'll ask for more of the sauce they put on the tacos.  I don't know what it is, but it's so good that all I want is moar, moar, moar.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Wow. First expectations: it's a hole in the wall. There's a functioning sink arms length to a table. Smells are questionable to give perspective.  We asked the waitress what we should order and she practically pointed at everything. Boy was she right! We ordered a plate called poc-choc (which was like a carne asada plate on a skillet). It was tender and flavorful.  We ordered one "panucho" and a "salbute"...we ate those within minutes they were so delicious. And lastly a Caldo de res which tasted fresh and made with a twist. We also ordered a a Agua Fresca called Cebada and it was very sweet (we had to dilute with water)

SO DELICIOUS!! We are tourist and we walked 20 minutes to get here. Worth it!
author: Kevin C.

description: This is an authentic Mexican restaurant in San Francisco. Pretty simple menu and tasty food. The chicken tamales are super good. The masa is cooked evenly and compliments the chicken filling well. The chicken empanada was really good and great with the onion/cabbage sides. I enjoyed the food here and want to try the tacos next time.
author: Ismael P.

description: This little Tenderloin gem serves up some delicious, authentic panuchos, empanadas, tamales, and tacos.  The carne asada, carnitas, and chicken are tender and perfectly seasoned no matter how they are delivered. Homemade tortillas, piping hot salsa, and friendly service round out the experience. I can't wait to try the soups!
author: Christine C.

description:
I am not familiar with Yucatán cuisine but I had an asada plate and a taco, both were okay, but I don't want to eat it again. The tortilla was too thick, and beans were all over and too liquid. I was hungry so I ate it but no, I do t want to go back. 
Total with tip was $20, which is a bit too much for what it is.
author: Anelya S.

description: It was right down the black from our hotel and had to give it a try.  Wasn't into fine dining but I got to tell you it was such a true to roots kind of place.  Didn't understand much English so we did the point to the picture thing.  The food was great.  I got the chicken and chicken soup that had such great flavors.  The kids got the sizzling pepper steak dish.  The black bean purée was also very good.  Loved the tamales!  And what a bargain!  4 dinners, 4 appetizers 4 sodas for 74.66.  Walked out completely full
author: Diane M.

description: I had a cold, and I felt so fortunate to discover this place around the corner from my hotel. To my delight, they had a LIST of soups to choose from -  my favorites were the puchero (chicken noodle soup) and the caldo de res (beef-broth based soup). After four days of bone-broth soup (they actually ran out of chicken soup on the last day - perhaps I ran them dry?), I felt good as new! Their tamales and tortillas are also really good and taste freshly made!
author: Tammy K.

description: Little hole in the wall place, not much to look at. But the food is amazing! Fresh homemade tortillas and perfect carne asada.
author: Linda L.

description:
Far from the taquerias of the Mission and below the bulgogi burritos of Nob Hill, El Rincon is an oasis north of Market street.

When I want to grab something quickly I'll order a couple of Panuchos (a fried tortilla stuffed with black beans) with carnitas or maybe a Salbute (puffed fried tortilla) with pollo.

When I have time to sit, enjoy the spanish-speaking music videos, and sip on some jamaica (a salty/sweet hibiscus drink) - I'll go with the Pollo Asado or Cochinita plates.

Their Pollo Asado is crazy good - it's a large roasted chicken leg that's marinated in some delicious sauce, with greens, pickled onions, and of course tortillas on the side.

But what I keep coming back for is the Cochinita - pork stewed until perfection with a plate of diced pickled onions, cabbage, and habanero with sides of rice, beans, and tortillas. Hey, you can even order their tacos with cochinita meat (I highly recommend).

One thing that can't be neglected is their hot SAUCE. This salsa is equally flavorful as it is spicy. The spice kicks in fast, but quickly levels out - but the flavor remains and is a perfect compliment to any dish.

Staring at the bucket of bright orange habaneros on the table over from me, watching the families chuckle and enjoy their meals, while simultaneously feeling the satisfying burn of the salsa - makes this restaurant all too perfect.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I loved it.  It's like your mom or gramma from the Yucatan  is in the kitchen making everything homemade.

I tried to order two each of the appetizers, and thankfully the waitress stopped me and said just get one each because they are big!  She was right! 

I loved the panucho the best, a tortilla with black beans spread on bottom and then layered with chicken, avocado, etc.  The other appetizer, was less complex.  The empanada (I ordered the cheese only one) was really good, but a little boring being only cheese so I'd try a meat one next time.

The soup with two bone in chicken thighs was delish.

We took two flans to go. They are huge, in a plastic cup.

June 24, 2017

Poc chuc grilled marinated pork

Both panucho pork and chicken

Both empanadas pork and cheese
author: Foodlover B.

description: OMG this was the some of the best food I've ever had!!!!!  Very unique and diverse dishes that I haven't seen before.  The location is a little low rent but the food will more than make up for it!
author: Michael D.

description: Great food. Best Yucateco food I ever tried. Working with yucatecos for several years . This is the b st cohinita pibil  in my life. And super nice friendly people .
author: Joe C.

description:
Pork empanada Was incredible. Hole in the wall definitely describes this place. But rightly so. Looks don't mean much when your chowing down on some authentic food. I'm a huge lover of good food and great service. This place is my kind of food fair. 

Don't be shy, be adventurous. try something you've never had before. You just might find your next favorite thing. 

This place is right around the corner from my new job and I can't wait to see what else they are making. 

I also ordered a chicken taco, it came with rice, lettuce, cabbage and a slice of avocado. The chicken wasn't as fresh as I had hoped but the empanadas made up for that. I will say that the tortilla was incredibly delicious. Fresh and thick.
author: Kat D.

description:
The cochinita Pibil is not it, service is good but is not clean, the tortilla is home made, place is not like the real one in Merida
Sorry but is not good place to eat
author: Rosa R.

description: Inside it is quite tiny and located in an area that scares off most tourists. I felt very at home and relaxed inside, it's definitely a neighborhood locals hangout. Our group ordered across the menu and everything was fantastic. Flavor, setting, and value make this a five star spot for people who want to get away from crowds and fusion tacos to have a very satisfying meal.
author: Katy H.

description:
TL;DR - GO EAT THIS FOOD.  MAKE SURE YOU'RE HUNGRY.

Man, oh man.  Panuchos, salbutes ... I had no idea what these beautiful masa creations were until I ordered them on a whim, and was not disappointed.  A beautiful, cheap, filling appetizer to start off before one of the best plates of carne asada that I've ever had.

This place was fantastic.  Incredible amounts of delicious food for a fantastic price.  Wonderful homemade tortillas with every entree.  Great rice and beans - simple, but tasty.

And that habanero hot sauce on the table?  Wow.  Delicious and incredibly spicy.  Eater beware.
author: Alex T.

description: Best Mexican food ! If you like the Yucatán style it's a don't miss ! And if you have never tried it you have to !! Never had a bad meal and the staff are really great :)
author: Niamh R.

description: Hole in the wall with great price to value. I got the carne asada plate which came with carne asada, onions, peppers, avocado slices, beans, rice, and homemade tortillas for $15. Not the fanciest of flavors but everything was extremely well executed and tasted great. Will definitely come again. One downside is that it is in the tenderloin and females may want to come with someone. If this place were in the Mission it would be packed!!!
author: Kenzan T.

description: Things were a little hit or miss, but the hits were OUTSTANDING. The mixed Empanada and Salbute are where it's at. The taste for the money makes this place a real gem. The panucho was good but I wouldn't get it over the other two items I mentioned. I didn't try the tamales but maybe next time. Skip the tacos.
author: Straker C.

description: Upon walking in I was turned off by the smell.  It smelled very dirty but sat down anyway as i was with a party of 10.  As soon as we sat down we saw a roach crawling on the floor!  We left immediately. I'm shocked that this place has 4.5 stars but I guess the food is good. I wont be trying it.  There are so many other paces in San Francisco that have great Mexican food and are Clean!
author: Alicia Z.

description: Yummy tamales for cheap. I ordered a side of beans and got home to realize I'd just paid $3 for a bowl of bean juice and not one bean.
author: Stephanie O.

description:
TOWNHALL MEETING NOW!!!!!

BEST MEXICAN FOOD EVER!!!! This place is off the freaking chain. It is the definition of hole in the wall - in other words, some people will feel almost uncomfortable just going here because it is very hole in the wall-ish - I guess what I am saying is don't bring your Marina girlfriend here. But cool laid back people will be blown away. It is literally like you have stepped into Mexico for an hour while you eat. They only do plates i.e. carne asada plates, or soups. Seriously, if you like Mexican food, you simply OWE YOURSELF to try this place out - just trust me on this and you can send me a thank you message later!
author: Nolan M.

description: Overall good meal, probably would have been even better a little earlier in the day! Authentic and friendly service and restaurant. Priced right!
author: Lexi B.

description: So good. Superior freshness, excellence across the menu, on cusp of mainstream discovery atm.
author: Jack L.

description: Great cheap find, friendly server and excellent food. This is not an upscale place, scratched paint, serviceable restroom, but 2 big lunches for $25 is a really good deal in pricey San Francisco.
author: Linda C.

description: In SF for a conference at the Hilton and needed a faster option than the crowded hotel options.  1 block away was this very modest and incredibly yummy Mexican joint with Yucatán fare.  Loved it!  I eat a lot of Mexican food and this was special.  Had a chicken and pork Panucho and wish this place in LA.
author: Dave R.

description: Possibly the best Mexican food I've ever had. I had the Carne Asada plate and it was delicious. The hot sauce was great too. As another reviewer said, the place is a little run down and the neighborhood isn't the nicest, but the food is totally worth it.
author: Carl O.

description:
I really couldn't give you a coherent description of Yucatecan cuisine probably because I couldn't find it on Wikipedia, but hey, I never said I was an expert. Oh sure, I've been to Poc-Chuc, Yucatasia, and both locations of Mi Lindo Yucatan (both sadly closed). I've even been to the Yucatan, but I honestly couldn't describe it as anything more than Mexican with a Cuban-Caribbean twang. The twang comes from the predominant use of pork and chicken usually marinated in achiote, a sweet-spicy red sauce native to the Yucatan, or some kind of citrus for a tropical kick. Hey, that's pretty good for a Yucatecan luddite. All I know is it's Latin comfort food I genuinely like if it's prepared by people who know how.

I came upon this place only because it showed up on my Yelp app, and it was a pretty easy ride on the 38 for me to get there. It's actually catty-corner from Bourbon & Branch, so there may be some hipster spillover here but not the evening I was there. In fact, there was only one other customer there, a fellow Asian but with a pocket protector and a bigger smartphone than mine. Compensating I'm guessing. Judging from the menu, it definitely looks like they know their stuff here. I decided to try a specialty as a starter, the $2.50 Salbute, a handmade fried tortilla puff topped with pork, green leaf, marinated red onions and avocado (photo: http://bit.ly/1Qzso4n). It had me at 'fried' as it was like a tostada with more character and definitely more flavor. I could have had a couple more and called it a night.

Since I just had the pork, I bypassed the Poc-Chuc for the $12 Pollo Asado, which was a whle chicken leg in achiote and again with the marinated red onions and avocado. This time it came with a side of rice, sliced tomatoes, sliced radishes and pureed black beans (photo: http://bit.ly/1jcDbXX). All the accessories tasted just fine, especially the fried tortillas (photo: http://bit.ly/1KRADss), but it was unfortunately hamstrung by how overcooked the chicken was. I was bummed because I thought I was safe with dark meat but alas it was left in the port too long. However, that won't stop me from a return visit. I noticed there were several women in the kitchen busily preparing all the food (though for whom, I wasn't sure). Plenty of other home-style dishes to try if I gird my loins tight enough through the 'Loin.

FOOD - 3 stars...stellar salbute but the poultry refused to fly
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...typical Tenderloin spot short on ambiance
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...nice enough
TOTAL - 3 stars...could I tell you more about Yucatecan cuisine?
author: Ed U.

description: This is a great hole in the wall, authentic Mexican joint that is well priced and extremely tasty. It has become one of my favorite Mexican restaurants in the city given how flavorful their food options are, their ingredients are fresh, and their service is quick and convenient. This place is not for the average gringo looking to get a California burrito. This place is for those that want a true authentic taste of southern Mexico.
author: Sebastian B.

description: Authentic Mexican food that is very affordable.  I had the chicken and pork tacos, and both were terrific with pork being the better of the two.  Atmosphere is simple and what you would expect for the price level; you go for the food, not the ambiance.
author: Derek W.

description:
They make their own tortillas. The food is good. 

Although enough has been said, the Yelp app insists I write more or be condemned to being a tipster. In my experience, things that end in ipster suck. For example, hipsters suck. Fortunately, there were none in this restaurant. I will continue writing because of the message, "Sweet deets. Now put some mustard on that review!"

The dining experience was normal. The restaurant had a few tables. The tables had either two or four chairs. There was and probably still is a sink in the dining room. People brought us food. The food is the primary impetus for the review; we ordered several food items. I recommend the poc chuc and carne asada. I haven't had the latter, but it smelled and sounded good as they gave it to the guy at the table next to us. 

The service was adequate. As I mentioned, people brought us food. Our server was lovely. I think my server was overwhelmed by the intense, positive feelings I expressed after tasting the tortillas. 

I once heard, "You wrote the pants off that review. We salute you." I agree. This review is epic. The food is probably only three star quality, but the homemade tortillas add a few stars. If you read this much on Yelp you have too much time on your hands. 

At this point, you may be wondering how I fit so little information into so much text. I feel obliged to provide an answer. I also have to get off BART.
author: Cosmo C.

description: Dropped in for dinner.  Amazing authentic mex food.  Home made corn tortillas, ridiculously good habenaro hot sauce ( i'm Korean, and used to heat - it was tasty and had major heat - much pleasure in the pain :D).  Decor sucked - but that's not why I went - if you want an amazing mex meal, this place is the real deal...btw, married into mex family (22 years) I like to think I know good mex food.
author: Gene K.

description: Hello, first timer.. ordered the carne asada plate. It was tasteful and very delicious. They have homemade tortillas, really good. Will have to return on my next trip!!!
author: Rosa R.

description: Always great to find authentic food in the middle of the big city ! Not another American Mexican food, the real stuff in the best way there is ! Must go
author: Gal Z.

description: Get the Tamale and Stay away from the hot sauce that they bring to your table. They didn't give me a warning, it was HOTTTTTTT!! I was craving tamale so I searched this place out. I was little disappointed that they only have have Chicken Tamale. But it's worth it. Very delicious. My husband got the empanadas and he loved it too.
author: Tra N.

description:
Ambience: Very small, crowded and older. It was not inviting, but when there are only native speakers there, one knows it's good. Oddly, to get to the restroom, you need to walk through the middle of the kitchen.
Service: Very slow, but cordial and I know there were some language barrier differences, so I don't put a lot of weight on this. 
Food: Wow! Such good food- good portions, perfectly cooked, and surprisingly classy for such a hole in the wall. I ordered the carne asada, and my buddy ordered the chicken. We were both incredibly surprised and happy at the tastiness of the dishes. I wish this place was closer!!!
author: Ryan S.

description: I wish I could give NO stars . Staff is just rude. Food is nothing special , not sure where all these other yelp reviews have dined but this is definitely not all that and a bag of chips. Takes forever to get your order and it's wrong! The rice tasted rancid/old not fresh at all, the same empanadas  were drenched in oil barely edible beans were ok the sopa de códitos was disgusting to say the least strong taste of the egg and panchos weren't bad I guess but you can definitely find much better elsewhere. Only thing good I have to say about this place is that the tortillas are about the only good thing here. Won't be coming back unless I'm starving even then I probably wont. I don't recommend it in the very least .
author: Maribel M.

description: I was so impressed by this place! We went tonight and they didn't include the appetizer I ordered in our to-go order. When I called to clear up this discrepancy the lady on the phone told the gentleman that we ordered from that the "gringo" had an issue. Great food but so disappointed in the treatment of their customers. I hope they can make the proper staffing adjustments because they have a seriously tasty product.
author: Kellen M.

description:
Passing through San Francisco from another Latino Hub (Denver)... But this is something else! Wow. I've never had such a juicy tamale, or such a tasty panucho. 
The atmosphere feels like being in a foreign country, hosted by some familia's grandmother. 
If I lived in this city, this would be a regular lunch spot for me!
author: Jennifer P.

description: Not the friendliest service but the food was good. Got the panuchos and a sope, no meat. I'll come back since it's by my parking garage and the spicy salsa is actually spicy. Total hole in the wall and not super clean but it's worth it for the price and food.
author: Ruby S.

description: Fresh tortillas! This is authentic cooking. If you are feeling adventurous, head to this hole in the wall. The neighborhood leaves more to be desired but once you are inside this spot and eating this food  you'll be happy you ventured out.
author: Heryka K.

description:
Definitely a hole in the wall... definitely delicious! I tried their Carne Asada plate and they turned me into a believer of black beans! I never eat black beans! Lol

Don't come in here expecting Michoacán/Jalisco/SanFrancisco Mexican food. They don't even sell burritos. But this Carne Asada plate was fantastic!

Also, beware their hot sauce, I almost choked on it and I like my food spicy!

I think they cook their Asada with Soy Sauce, which at first sounds weird but then makes perfect sense.

I will come here again if I have the opportunity.
author: Anthony D.

description: Damn good food. Damn good flavor. Damn good prices. Three items at $3.20 each and you'll be full. Panucho and empanada are my go to in addition to the caldo de res (beef broth soup).
author: Edwin S.

description:
Very enjoyable lunch. Great food. Hole in the wall, ethnic atmosphere. This is real food like in actual Mexico. 

I got the Poc-Chuc, thin sliced pork with thick tortillas, avocado, cabbage, salsa, and a quarter habanero pepper. Yum. $13 for a very generous portion, could have been shared for a lighter lunch. 

Friendly staff. No frills. Real deal traditional regional food. 

More to explore on the menu... I will go back next time I am in town.
author: Adam R.

description: I grew up in Mexico and very picky about GOOD authentic Mexican which is hard to find in SF. This little hole in the wall was a big surprise. Try their panuchos and empanadas they are both exquisite down to the sauce they are served with
author: guy k.

description:
Wow in hole in the heart of the Tenderloin.
Try 2 apps for a early Lunch.
Family run business, all ingredients top notch.

1st app a flatten black bean purée seared into the corn tortilla top with fresh shredded chicken with red onion and garnish with garlic. Brown orange sauce added a nice kick.

2nd app Fresh made Empanada with fresh ground pork. I have try many Empanada(s). This one was the best ever.

Excellent price to quality value.
Definitely will be back for an entree 
when l am in the area.

l am back late Lunch before Work Sunday, March 12th.
author: Food Sage W.

description: I came here with my friend after he insist, he said they have best steak ever, I tried to order the steak he suggested , the waiter was so rude, I asked to change the sauce to a different one since I'm allergic to soy, he refused and said this is the way we serve it and we don't change any of the ingredient, even I asked for mashed potatoes also he was rude with his answer, any way my friend ordered his food and I didn't, I'm giving them 2 stars because my friend said the food is good, but service and hygiene level is not at all
author: Prince O.

description: Honestly, the food was a little dry. The staff took forever considering there was not that many people in the restaurant to begin with. And the food was overpriced for what it was. With that said everyone has different tastes buds. So you might have a different experience.
author: G A.

description: The food tasted unflavored and seemed like it was rushed.  The chicken was okay. Everything else had NO flavor or sauce.  Very small place. There was a random sink in the corner which set off the atmosphere.
author: Mutale M.

description: I got the pork tamale and I received my order in less than five minute with the fork and two sauce within my bag. Quick service that leaves me satisfied. I will be back because it was affordable for SF price.
author: Mimi B.

description:
Q: What is better than panuchos, salbutes, and empanadas from El Rincon?

A: Absolutely nothing.  This is comfort food at its finest.

One of my most favorite places to eat in the neighborhood (other than Huxley).

Haven't managed to order an entree yet, because I keep coming back with cravings for the masa-based creations.
author: Lauren D.

description:
El Rincon Yucateco offers mexican cuisine, yucatecan style. takes over a spot that sold pizza, chicken before. 

menus: mains, tamales, empandas, panucho, salbute, ...

eats: 
beef empanada(2.5)
-beef or cheese, choose beef, premade and cooked when ordered?
typical empanada but cheaperm as good as the $5 ones at farmers markets
 punucho(2.5)
-"refried hand made tortillas with fresh tasty carnitas, black beans, chopped cabbage,red onions, avocado, pickled jalepeno peppers"
-tasty,
-comes with chopped garnish, red sauce (looks same as pupusa sauce).

crumbs:
-small eats worthy, not sure about mains
-limited dining space, 
-tenderloin maybe iffy in the evenings.
3.5 stars for spicy uniquenes, good value....
author: Victor G.

description:
Thank goodness we found this place-- they get 5/5 for their service: friendly smiles, attentive staff, very welcoming atmosphere, and of course their very delicious food. Omg. For the food they get a 100/5. Haha 

Ok let's start with the beverages. They have freshly squeezed OJ and homemade horchata. They're of course delicious. The coffee is very savory too. 

Anyway to the dishes. We ordered three panuchos ($2.70 each) one of chicken, other of pork, and third of beef. Wow. They are, which all honesty, one of the most savory dishes I have had in my life.  Very very flavorful.... you can tell this is a mama and pop's recipe and a very authentic Yucatán dish. You cannot leave this place without tasting these. 

We ordered a Carne asada plate  ($14) and we shared. They bring you a ton of home made tortillas so make tacos out of this dish!!! The carne asada is amazing. I don't know how they cook it but wow. Very flavorful... juicy... tender. 

Anyway the three of us ate and are super full and very satisfied for $36. If you're in SF-- you have to come here. Thankfully we are at 1 minute walking distance :)
author: Leslie O.

description: It's a bit prices if you go with a family! But it has a delicious taste to it! The only problem i had was that i asked for orange juice and the head lady told me they had none and they were making none the whole day, so I was like oh okay. But then when locals came In she took out almost 10 orange juice  for everyone else but didn't even take a look on me.
author: Cynthia O.

description: Came here for what was suppose to be a small diner. Hubby had the carne Asada and it was super yummy. I had a taco, a tamal and an empanada. All we're pretty good. But! Hubbys plate was super yummy. Will definitely go back for that whenever we're in town again.
author: Mayra A.

description: What a great late night spot... we ordered several plates..and everything was deeeeelicious.  Not the traditional taco shop.. each crafted with tons of flavors and sides to compliment..
author: E L.

description:
The place is a bit dingy and the neighborhoood gritty, but this little hole in the wall restaurant delivers on the food.
The beef broth is my favorite dish here. Just a very comforting and hearty dish that is executed well with fresh ingredients. Big chucks of beef with rib still in it along with chopped up squash and carrot. The broth is rich with meaty flavors and the sweetness of the vegetables. Homemade corn tortilla is served as a side, and they are absolutely delectable with amazing texture. (thicker than the usual tortillas from mexican restaurants, you can smell the freshness of the homemade corn tortilla). Fresh radishes and salsa provides a nice complement to the dish. The salsa has a pretty nice kick of heat, so be careful not to douse your tortilla with it, but the flavors are complex and provides a nice boost of acidity and punch to everything you add them to. They also serve a little bowl of coconut rice that is velvety, puffy, and plain delicious.
Service is prompt, but again, you definitely come here for the food not the ambiance. Definitely give this place a try, especially if you haven't explored Yucatan cuisine.
author: Austin T.

description:
I ordered a weekend special soup and was not impressed. The place was very noisy because of the echoey interior, kitchen noise, and a loud TV.

I may come back again, but I wouldn't order a soup. The other dishes looked much better.
author: David S.

description:
I'm working my way through the menu, and have yet to be disappointed with what I ordered. The ground pork empanadas are amazingly delicious. I generally stick to ordering several of the smaller things to make a meal, and as a result, I get to taste the different styles of marinated porks. I ordered 3 items that were less than $3.00 a piece. Also, I've had a gastric sleeve surgery, and can't eat a whole bunch- and their portions are huge(another reason I order small.)I still have leftovers for lunch tomorrow...  I love the marinated cabbage and red onions that they served with my taco, empanadas, and other deliciously fried tortilla goodness I put in my mouth. This restaurant  was full of people who seemed to be enjoying some home-style food, because the patrons were all speaking Spanish. It's the real authentic deal over here, with fantastic prices. I overheard that they took debit, but I always bring cash. 
Tip- the hot sauce in the squeeze bottle is FIRE..like for real- my mouth was singed.
author: Robin W.

description: The food was delicious! I ordered an empanada, a tamale,  sopa de coditos and some carne asada. The tamale was ok, the empanada was really hood eapecially with the tomato sauce on top, the sopa was good and the chicken in the sopa was seasoned really well! Carne asada was ok. The waitress was absent minded and kept forgetting our drinks, ended up getting the drinks halfway through the meal. Place was clean and prices were good!
author: Jacky C.

description: This is the absolute best Mexican food I've had in San Francisco. The tamale was wonderful it was wonderful, and Poc-Chuc was unbelievably tasty. 6 stars.
author: Kevin A.

description: I heart the staff, food, and atmosphere. Everything is right and you leave fully satisfied. :)
author: John M.

description:
This place is amazing. My friends and I came here for dinner tonight before a play at the Curran. We only had 15 minutes to order and eat before our play started, but the staff here were super nice and made our delicious food in record time, and packed it up to go for us and we ran out the door. The tacos and empanadas were great. 

Muchisimas gracias a todos por la comida super rica y su servicio incredible. Vamos a regresar en el futuro cuando no tenemos mucha prisa :)
author: Claire F.

description: Outstanding! Don't let the "hole in the wall" scare you away. Great flavors and ample food. Super value too. Carne asada was super. Hot sauce very different and extremely tasty. Not just your normal hot, but very spicy and flavorful. I'll definitely be back!
author: John C.

description: This is really excellent authentic mexican food in town, it is great services and really tasty food  Yucatan style , yeah different but good , highly recommend,  thanks
author: Jose M.

description: This place is amazing! Delicious Mexican food with an authentic, homey feeling. The place is clean and comfortable, no frills, staff is nice. You will find no burritos or fajitas here, but fresh tacos, empanadas, tamales and meat plates. The carne asada plate was amazing, served with rice, onions, peppers and black beans (very good btw). So was the Poc-Chuc (thinly sliced, grilled marinated pork that comes in its skillet with tender onions, avocado, salad and black beans). The tortillas are fresh, thick and delicious. The plates are big and filling, and you definitely get very high quality food, super fresh, for a very low price.  Definitely give it a try!
author: Carole C.

description: Overcharged by adding two items we did not order and after we paid and got the receipt and pointed out the mistake, they still tried to give us the wrong change. The food is decent but only worth the price actually listed on the menu.
author: Meredith S.

description:
Slightly scary neighborhood and a small restaurant.  We weren't sure if we should have dinner there.  No chips and salsa.  

But the food we ordered was amazingly authentic and very good.   Cheap and yummy Mexican fix.
author: Tim M.

description: Great find. Delicious tacos and tamales. Open late, what else could you ask for? I recommend for any one  that has a late night hankering for homemade mexican food.
author: Ben Z.

description:
This. Place. Is. Amazing. 

So far, I've tried the carne asada plate (a gazillion times), empanadas, tacos, and the salbutes. Everything is an A+. The carne asada plate is my particular favorite, because it comes with delicious sides, that are perfect in such nuanced ways. This description will not articulate the nuances, because it is difficult, but the rice is perfectly cooked, the tortillas are TO DIE FOR (and freshly made every day), and the carne asada is seasoned so well, with bell peppers and onions. The hot sauce is extremely spicy, so be careful. Though the empanadas and salbutes are deep fried (and I am someone who values clean/not heavy food), they are not greasy or too heavy. Just delicious. 

I got pretty excited writing this review, but all this to say, please don't ever leave us.
author: Lillian K.

description: I was blown away. Exceeded expectations. Had their cochinita pibil and Some hand fried taco thing and my stomach is singing.  I will be back.
author: reza n.

description: This place is truly amazing. The food is full of flavor. I was wowed by every thing. It's officially my new spot when I come back to visit San Francisco  I definitely recommend this place to EVERYONE !!!
author: Sandra J.

description: Tamale was good, but the pollo tacos were average. One of our tacos had a large bone in it. Shan't be back.
author: Todd N.

description: Wow! what a treat. First time here. Simple place and located in the edge of the upper Tenderloin. I had the carne asada came on a sizzling plater smother with onions and bell peppers. Also came with 3 hand made tortillas. A side of rice and beans were  a nice touch.  I will go back!
author: Hum V.

description:
This place is delicious! Affordable, fresh, and authentic. I used to eat here at least two to three times a week when I lived down the street. I was slightly obsessed.

At first glance, their modest menu might seem like you don't have a ton of choices but don't let that get you down. Everything is fantastic! 

Also, don't be fooled by the tiniest amount of salsa they give you. At first I was like, these folks are so cheap! My mistake!! They know exactly what they're doing. It's pure habanero FIRE! You only need a few drops and you're set. But you've been warned, it well set your mouth ablaze! 

Give this place a shot if you're in the TL. FYI it's cash only!
author: Mel F.

description: Best Mexican food in SF!! If you like homemade and authentic Mexican food then this is the place to go.  Best tortillas and empanadas ive ever had.  Every meAt plate n soup are great as well.
author: Anthony A.

description: I had a colado tamale and it was amazing and I'm very picky with yuca tan food since I'm from their this place was very yummy I'm glad we tried it out
author: Sarlet P.

description: Holy Lord is the food terrific! The location is the deterrent that would prevent someone to try this place out because it's full of Riff Raff out front, and the inside looked ancient, but the food is the main draw. I ordered the Carne Asada entree that comes with rice and beans and PLENTY of tortillas. Also, the tamales and the chicken Panuchos and they were well seasoned and generously seasoned.
author: N A.

description: Looking for a place to get a quick lunch so I decided to try this out.  Looks can be deceiving because this is a small restaurant, basic tables, a very no frills set up; but the food I ordered was delicious.  Appetizers were plenty enough for lunch because they are large portions so I only ordered two.  Good food and good service!
author: Susan M.

description: This place is incredible!! It's no frills and nothing fancy but the food is just amazing every time. My boyfriend loves the steak (marinated in soy sauce) and I've been making my way down their extensive list of soups. But the tamales are the real standout here. It you're looking for Americanized mexican, this isn't the place for you. But if you want authentic food made with love, run over now!
author: Megan Z.

description: This little hole in the wall was absolutely the bomb. We wanted to taste a few things and share so we got the Carnitas Torta, Chicken Torta, two pork and two chicken tamales, Carne Asada plate, two chicken tacos and two chicken Panuches. Everything was delicious and very fairly priced. The Torta's were huge and 8.50, the tacos were 2.50 each as were the tamales and super tasty. Carne Asada plate was 12$ and I couldn't buy the amount of skirt steak they gave us for that alone. We could have fed the 4 of us for under 25$ (two adults and two kids) but went overboard on purpose and it was 56$ and worth every penny.
author: Jay B.

description: Hole in the wall Mexican with good food in the heart of hotel area. Unique dishes not found elsewhere, excellent tortillas. Not much atmosphere but felt very authentic.
author: Olivia W.

description: The side and 2 main dishes were great.  I would go back to try more.  The tortillas we fresh and homemade.  The flan was copious and a bit bland.
author: Megan W.

description: This place is an authentic gem! I sampled a few things from the menu and it was all ridiculously good. Prices are super cheap and the staff is super friendly. It is cash only but not a big deal at all considering the great prices. If you are in the area and want authentic Mexican food you should definitely check this place out. Yum!
author: David B.

description:
I have to say that this place is a gem. It might not look like a lot but the food is great. 

I had the pork plate for take out. The flavor a are unlike anything you've had before. It's not Mexican, so don't expect carne asada and guac.

The pork was seasoned nicely. There were a few very fatty bits that I had to pull out, but that's standard. The tortillas were handmade and really fresh. The black bean sauce is excellent, but I almost wish it were thicker. I really enjoyed the cabbage slaw that came with it. 

There were a few things on the men is like to try next and I'm sure they are all great. I highly recommend you head to the TL and check this place out instead of your standard taco shops.

Prices are reasonable at $12 for a plate. $2.50 for individual tacos, empanadas and tamales.
author: Sarah S.

description: The first item on the menu, forgot what it's called.. But got two of them and they are out of this world, I definitely recommend this to taco lovers/enthusiasts. For the price they are worth the try. Really nice.
author: Jones B.

description: My family and I came from on out of town and ate a great home cooked meal. I had mondongo (aka menudo) and my wife had the caldo de res. It was authentic. I wish Los Angeles had more places like this (or maybe it does and I need to explore more). We will come again!
author: Wendell O.

description: It is a tiny little whole in the wall and it is one of the best Mexican places I have come across. Comparing the food to my families cooking and living in Tijuana, these  foods are  definitely up to par. Great comfort food that reminds me of home.
author: A P.

description: Yum! So good. Anything with pork is outstanding and you can't beat the price. Tortillas are amazing. Great services, food came out hot and fast. Anytime I'm in San Francisco I'm going here.
author: Jay S.

description: Divey casual great Mexican food. Authentic with the flavors of the Yucatan. Empanadas are terrific. Pork dishes also a highlight. Fresh tasty tortillas.
author: Mark L.

description: Was excited to try this hole in the wall restaurant next to my hotel after reading rave reviews. However, my experience here was less than ideal. The food was delicious and the price was great for what you get. The service is where I felt this little restaurant was lacking. It took 20 mins to get our order taken, and another 45 minutes to get our bill. When I tried to stand at the counter to pay our bill the waitress would blatantly ignore me and walk past me while avoiding eye contact. Go here only if you have a lot of extra time.
author: Charlene R.

description: A hole-in-the-wall Mexican restaurant. AMAZING food! The prices are cheap, the food tastes authentic and wonderful. The homemade tortillas are a must buy. I highly recommend visiting! The service was very fast and we barely waited for food. It's a small place, perfect for lunch.
author: Catie M.

description:
A good new restaurant in Tenderloin/TenderNob area. 
Yucateca cuisine for meat Lovers. My partner (African-American guy) ordered Sopa de Coditos with chicken and he loved it. 
For vegetarians like me, you have the options to request some of the appetizers or entrées without meat.
I ordered Empanadas (quesadillas) without cheese and server with cabbage, onions, habanero sauce and lime.
Be careful my people, Yucatecos use a lot habanero chilli. Ask for non spicy or little spicy if you can't handle.
The place is too small so I recommend order for to go. But for those leaving the bars around the area is a good option to eat some food before back to home!!
author: Arturo R.

description: Pleasantly surprised and would definitely go back.  Simple interior and tasty food.  Unique items I haven't seen anywhere else.  Go for the pork!
author: Derek F.

description: Ordered the fish fillet with salad, comes with black rice and beans.  The fish fillet was likely frozen fried fish fillets.  Worse than what you would get at McDonalds.  Salad was very good, had avocado in it.  Rice and beans tasty as well.  Service was pleasant.  I'd try this place again... perhaps the pork or chicken is better?
author: Tom L.

description: This place is amazing. Very affordable and great flavor. The staff is supper friendly. When the food arrives you know it's fresh. Highly recommend.
author: Jason W.

description: Excellent hole in the wall restaurant near union square. This place serves authentic food from Yucatán. Better than most trendy places in the area.
author: Tony O.

description: It's very good, the food is fresh, and the empanadas were so crispy and  the panuchos were even better,, Fast service too.
author: Alberto S.

description: Cochinita taco, get it, eat it, enjoy it.  The waitress was awesome in recommending this. Bomb food, delicious.
author: Noe G.

description: Flat-out outstanding. There was a Yucatan restaurant a couple blocks away that closed a few years ago and they had a few dishes this place doesn't have, but everything I've gotten there has been absolutely delicious. And the poc chuc is crazy good. I live a couple blocks away but would actually make a special trip to the neighborhood for the poc chuc. Prices are super reasonable too.
author: Sean F.

description: Authentic food a a decent price. Loved the chicken taco the most! Definitely worth a stop!
author: Jared T.

description: Yummy salbutes and tamales! Sometimes they have arroz con leche and it is very tasty. Tenderloin gem. Support local businesses!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Small menu but uniformly good food.  Their hot sauce is one of the best I have ever had.
author: Dan L.

description: I am from Yucatan. So I feel I have the right to judge. What an amazing dinner. Service was amazing. Food was just like being home.  So so authentic. A must have if you are in town. Do not expect your traditional Mexican food, because Yucatan cuisine is so very unique. I could eat here every day. So happy to have found this gem.
author: Ali F.

description: If you are looking for a real mexican food, this id the place. Delicious, great prices !!
author: Hilda P.

description: Had a panucho, tamale and 2 cochinita tacos. Beautifully served with a side of two salsas, a mild red for the tamale and a spicy habanero based green for the brave. Extra points for the homemade tortillas. Cochinita was probably some of the best I've had in the states. Great choice for a late night meal.
author: Ezra F.

description: It's the kind of place you probably wouldn't go in unless someone told you to. Well I'm telling you to! Absolute hole in the wall but the food was authentic and excellent! I had the Poc-Chuc which was very good, but the winner was the Panucho! It was so tasty, next time I may just get a bunch of those!
author: Anthony V.

description: this place is one of those hole in the wall places you usually walk right by, in this case....stop in.  The food is delicious, the portions are massive and the price is reasonable (like actually reasonable not San Francisco reasonable).  We came in late night, the service and food hit the spot. Def a strong recommend
author: Jordan T.

description: This is my favorite Mexican restaurant in San Francisco. Absolutely amazing and great value. Looking forward to coming back the next time!
author: David L.

description: Nice authentic little spot. Great place to get a giant bowl of soup or plate of chicken with some legit hot sauce and warm the soul.
author: citizen l.

description: Wow. This place is truly amazing.  No burritos here.  This is a reasonable price place to sample true Mayan cuisine.   I have never had anything I didn't like.  I dream of the food at night.   Especially the salbute.  Just try, doubt that you will be disappointed.
author: pilou o.
